We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has acute rheumatic fever, which is a complication of untreated streptococcal pharyngitis. The best step in management is Penicillin therapy to treat the underlying infection and prevent further complications. NSAIDs can be used for symptomatic relief of joint pain, but they do not address the underlying cause. Aortic valve replacement and mitral valve repair may be considered in cases of severe valve damage, but this is not indicated in this patient at this time.

The best step in management is penicillin therapy to eradicate streptococcal infection and prevent further progression of rheumatic fever. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and signs of acute rheumatic fever (ARF), which is caused by a previous streptococcal pharyngitis infection. Penicillin is the recommended treatment for streptococcal pharyngitis and for preventing recurrent ARF. Symptomatic relief with NSAIDs may also be given, but the main treatment is aimed at preventing further streptococcal pharyngitis episodes. Aortic valve replacement or mitral valve repair may be needed in severe cases of rheumatic heart disease, which is a long-term complication of ARF.
